title: Spice epidemic in jails exposed as prisoner dies after setting himself on fire while high on drug
text:
The Spice epidemic is so bad in jails that an inmate died after accidentally setting himself on fire while high on psychoactive drugs, the new prisons and probation ombudsman has revealed in her first annual report.

Sue McAllister said the 31-year-old’s life “might have been saved” had it not been for an “unacceptable” 16-minute delay by prison officers in responding to him ringing his cell’s emergency bell.

According to her report, N, a convicted robber in Hewell prison in Worcestershire and known frequent drug user, may not have reacted to being on fire initially “because he was under the influence of the drug”.

When staff entered the cell, they found him sitting on his bed with his clothes burned off and severe burns to most of his body. “He was conscious but appeared unable to comply with staff instructions,” said the report. He died two days later in hospital from his burns.

Ms McAllister said she had ordered a disciplinary inquiry into why the officer on duty took so long to respond in an apparent breach of rules that require staff to attend within five minutes of a bell being rung.

She cited the case as evidence that psychoactive substances continued to be a “serious problem” in jails with most prison governors telling her they were struggling to deal with the surge in Spice and psychoactive substances. There were up to 60 drug-related deaths in jails last year.
